title.narrative: WFAD: Friska unga - friska samhällen: Att omvandla våldsamma ungdomar i Kinshasa
WFAD: Sober Youth - Healthy Communities: Transforming Violent Youth in Kinshasa

description.narrative: The general objective of this contribution is to prevent young people from joining, and support others in leaving, the street gangs, whilst contributing to a strengthened drug policy in the country. In order to prevent and tackle urban violence, this intervention will introduce and support mechanisms for mentoring and empowering young people through psychosocial support, vocational training, entrepreneurship, socio-economic and social reintegration, for the positive development of youth in becoming contributing members of the community. Moreover, the capacities of partner organisations and network of organisations and stakeholders working against the social and socio-economic consequences of alcohol and drug use in the DRC will be strhengthened, and regional cooperation to share best practices will be developed to advocate for and create better preconditions to prevent youth from joining, and support others in leaving violent street gangs. As far as the theory of change is concerned, WFAD suggests a four levels of intervention to meet the needs of these young people: individual, family, community and institutional levels. The project will offer support in recovery and desistance from violence, criminal behaviour and illicit drug use, including parental support groups, and provide vocational training as well as income generating activities. Advocacy activities targeting key institutional stakeholders, including local authorities, police, and policymakers will enable the enhancement of credibility, cooperation between different actors/stakeholders. As well as possibility for replication and mainstreaming of the activities. The project offers a clear environmental dimension as it focuses on sanitation services and production of clean and affordable water, while offering clear gendered specific support.

Projektet syftar till att bidra till att förebygga våld bland ungdomarna i Kinshasa (inkl. gäng- och sexuellt våld samt användning av droger etc.) genom att övertyga dem att lämna våldsamma grupper, förse dem med psykosocialt stödd för att främja deras mentala hälsa och involvera dem i olika ekonomiska och sociala aktiviteter (inkomstgenererande aktiviteter, vatten och sanitet, yrkesutbildning) för sina egna personliga och samhälls välbefinnande. WFAD är den ledande organisation som kommer att ansvara för samordningen av projektet medan genomförandet kommer att skötas av fyra lokala organisationer. Förstärkningen av partnerorganisationerna utgör också en viktig del av projektet i och med att de kommer att engageras i det lokala och regionala nätverket mot narkotika och alkoholmissbruk. Detta är en annan aspekt av projektet som förväntas bidra till andra aspekter av fattigdomsbekämpning i de berörda områdena.

This project aims at preventing violence among the youth in Kinshasa (inkl. gang violence, sexual violence and use of drugs etc.) by promoting their mental health and involving them in various economic and social activities, including income generation activities, water and sanitation, and other vocational training for their own and their communities well-being. WFAD is the lead organisation in charge of the coordination of the project while the implementation will be carried out by four local partner organisations. The reinforcement of the partner organisations and engaging them in the local, regional and global anti-drugs network is another aspect of the project which is expected to contribute to other aspects of poverty alleviation in the targeted areas.

description.narrative: The progress realized during the first nine months or so of the programme have been significant. A few examples include: - DASOD has so far built three boreholes, which have have resulted among other things in water supply for 40 000 inhabitants in the Bagata and Mabulu neighborhoods of the municipality of Makala to resume for the first time since 2009. Tens of ex-members of Kuluna gangs have been involved in the manual works. Increase refinenement of the programme will involve developing the commercial component (packaging and selling of water) and hence stabilizing income generation for the youth. - Inter-Actions has kicked off its waste management component, with local schools, hospitals, hotels, stores, as well as 5 000 households already benefitting from the Programme activities. In addition to that, activities involving youths have allowed Inter-Actions to identify the so-called Kuluna teams (“écuries”), which is expected to benefit their outreach to the youth to get them involved in support sessions. Inter-Actions is expecting to hire at least 200 ex-members in the first year of the projects, with numbers expected to progressively grow. - SYFES has commenced its psychosocial sessions. The opening, gathering more than 100 young girls and their guardians has provided a powerful start to the Programme. SYFES is expecting to involve around 250 young girls during the first year of the project. These youth will be guided towards income generating activities (DASOD and Inter-Actions) and further education (formal or vocational) for which additional funding is being sought from USAID.
